Core Earth Religions.name: Core Earth Religions
Core Earth Religions.text:
Although Core Earth has a relatively low Spiritual Axiom compared to several of the invading realms, the immense Possibility Energy that pervades the cosm resulted in practically countless different legends, stories, and faiths. Even though miracle working was rare in Core Earth before the invasion, and the variety of invoked miracles was low, miracles are becoming more prevalent with each day as those who are

particularly pious encounterrr new miracles or learn to interpret their own faith in new ways.

This product gives a high level overview of the religions followed by most of the people on Core Earth, as well as provides additional Perks, miracle lists, and miracles that Storm Knights can use to take their battles to the forces of the High Lords.

New Perks

The following new Perks present more options for pulp powers, miracles, and new arcane traditions, as well as Perks supporting the over-the-top heroes and villains of the Nile Empire.

If a Perk lists Beta Clearance as a prerequisite it may only be taken once the Storm Knight achieves that clearance level (50+ XPs) or higher.

When a Perk boosts an attribute, it counts exactly the same as if the gainwere purchased by XPs. If the Perk is lost, so is the attribute bonus. The standard ceiling for a race’s attribute remains unchanged unless the Perk specifically increases it.

Faith Perks

No other cosm has a greater variety of faiths and religions than Core Earth. And although many of these Perks are well suited for the faithful who live in the targeted cosm, some are available to characters from other cosms as well. Those specific to Core Earth list this requirement in their prerequisites.

@Compendium[te001-core-rulebook.Items.XCJ9T9FLvflkWVfq]{Exorcist}, @Compendium[te001-core-rulebook.Items.lUPOd0c1NfFzw4Ux]{Fortified by faith}, @Compendium[te001-core-rulebook.Items.0hFYmCfPW5aEVYCw]{Pacifist}, @Compendium[te001-core-rulebook.Items.uc9kKIDlHSEWTbkA]{Religious Pluralist}, @Compendium[te001-core-rulebook.Items.EYaAXiSPMdjuyU1i]{Religious Scholar}, @Compendium[te001-core-rulebook.Items.GuZxatpaObCZzrK8]{Spirit Nemesis}, @Compendium[te001-core-rulebook.Items.WQB68Ad3LqDTbWlU]{Vow of Nonviolence}

Exorcisms

An exorcism is resolved as a Dramatic Skill Resolution with Steps that can be performed (or aided through a Combined Action) by anyone, but if the lead character does not have an ability that allows exorcism (e.g. the Exorcist Perk, or is bonded to a Compassion familiar), all tests to complete Steps are Disfavored. Other characters may participate by using interaction attacks or other abilities.

The exorcist invokes the banish miracle or cast out spell to complete the steps. The DN to complete a Step is equal to the possessor’s willpower or Spirit, but the DN increases by +2 for each subsequent Step after A. The possessor may make an Active Defense to increase the difficulty of completing the Step further. Otherwise the possessor can use its normal abilities to fight back, which can include direct physical, spiritual, or magical attacks, interaction attacks, or even summoning or conjuring allies.

In addition to the normal results from failing a Dilemma, there are additional consequences:

  • Possible Setback: The exorcist also becomes Vulnerable.
  • Complication: The exorcist takes Fatigue.
  • Critical Problem: The exorcist takes a Wound.

If the exorcist completes Step D, the possession is ended, and the spirit or demon is banished for a year and a day. If the exorcist fails to complete Step D in five rounds, the possession can only be ended through the death of the host.

Reality Perk

@Compendium[te001-core-rulebook.Items.Hl3u2hczuNbpqGZw]{Ascetic}

Religions

Bantu (and other traditional African faiths)

The Bantu comprise several hundred ethnic groups from sub-Saharan Africa, including East and Central Africa. They speak the Bantu family of languages, which includes Swahili. Bantu faith consists of animist tales and legends found in almost every Bantu culture, and is just one of many traditional African religions.

Although many of the people living in sub-Saharan African nations are predominantly Christian, this, and similar faiths, is spread throughout the southern half of the continent. It is also practiced among the Zulus, Xhosa, and other groups in South Africa.

Tenets

Common tenets of the Bantu faith include the following:

  • There exists a supreme, though vaguely defined, God. It’s often associated with the sun, and at other times the oldest possible ancestor. In Swahili, this God is known as Mungu. Depending on the specific culture, the supreme god lives in the sky or on a mountaintop. The supreme God is distant from mankind.
  • The universe is eternal. God didn’t create the universe, but is related to it. Animals also are eternal. In many stories, mankind was born from a plant or emerged from a cave.
  • They have many stories about the origin of death, including a race between a chameleon and a lizard. The chameleon would tell mankind they would live forever, whereas the lizard would tell them they would die. The lizard wins the race and mankind is fated to die. To this day chameleons and lizards are bad omens.
  • Spirits of the dead linger and influence the living, but only as long as someone who remembers them remains alive. With the exception of memorable chiefs and leaders, most spirits linger only for three generations. The spirits communicate via dreams or omens, or through seers.
  • Monsters exist and often are man-eaters. Some monsters can appear like men or animals, and some can transform humans into animals.

Bantu Seer

Worship

Because God is distant from mankind, followers of the Bantu faith worship by communing with ancestral spirits or lesser deities, often with the assistance of seers. They honor these spirits via the sacrifice of animals, food, flowers, and precious metals. Followers then ask their ancestors for a boon or sometimes for information.

After the arrival of Nile Empire axioms, these spirits take a much more real form, and the Bantu faith has enjoyed a particular resurgence over the past several months.

The bantu faith employs no established hierarchy. Followers worship in theirownway, although they may gain assistance of seers, who often can invoke miracles. The traditions of the Bantu faith pass from one generation to the next via oral tradition rather than via holy writings.

Bantu and the Possibility Wars

The belief in traditional African faiths is undergoing a significant increase with the arrival of the Reality Raiders (particularly the Nile Empire). With the arrival of the higher Spirit Axiom and exposure to new miracles, many are returning to their Bantu traditions and finding communication with spirits and animals useful. Like any other belief system, the Bantu faith is outlawed within the Nile Empire, but this does not discourage worship. Nile troops are still relatively scarce in the Congo. Many areas in East Africa experience full rebellion and plenty of folk are still willing to hide the religious (even those who are Muslims or Christians).

Additionally, creatures and monsters from Bantu mythology were recently sighted in the rainforests of the Congo and in Ethiopia. Some believe the many disappearances of people are due not to the actions of Nile

shocktroopers but rather to monsters of antiquity.

Buddhism

Originating in ancient India, Buddhism is the world’s fourth largest religion with more than 500 million followers. It is the dominant religion in southeast Asia, including Burma, Thailand, Vietnam, and Malaysia. A large number of Buddhists, followers of a variant called Zen, live in China, South Korea, and Japan. Although less than 20% of the population of China is Buddhist, the nation’s larger overall population means that it still holds the greatest number of followers—more than 200 million of them. Despite Buddhism’s origins in India, that subcontinent has relatively few adherents. Neighbouring Sri Lanka, on the other hand, is mainly Buddhist.

Male Buddhists are called monks, while female followers are called nuns.

Religions in Torg Eternity

This chapter includes details on various real-world faiths and religions, with enough information provided for players to roleplay a ‘typical’ member of those faiths. Summarizing complex world views and religions into a form usable for a game is fraught with peril, and even those who follow these faiths disagree on details. It’s difficult to treat the various faiths authentically without going into too much detail for what is ultimately a game, and while we attempted to ensure the accuracy of the text, there are bound to be some errors or details that were overlooked, or were tweaked to fit the setting of Torg Eternity.

Tenets

The term Buddhism comes from the word budhi, meaning to awaken, and many Buddhists consider it to be more of a philosophy rather than a religion. Siddhartha Gotama, a member of the royal family born in Nepal in the mid-500s BCE, reasoned that riches and power do not necessarily bring happiness. He achieved enlightenment after six years of study and meditation, and spent the rest of his life instructing others in Dhamma, which means Truth.

The basics of Buddhism are contained in the Four Noble Truths, as follows.

  • All life is suffering (not just physical, but psychological as well)
  • Suffering is caused by the desire for conditions and things which are not permanent
  • True happiness can be attained, and suffering can be overcome
  • The Noble Eightfold Path leads to the end of suffering
  • Other tenets of Buddhism include the following.
  • Karma, where peoples’ intentional actions influence their futures. Intentionally harming others leads to bad Karma, while helping others increases good Karma.
  • Rebirth. People live and die, whereupon a person’s nature—thoughts, feelings and perceptions—passes into a new body. The manner of rebirth is determined by the Karma accumulated during life. However, Buddhists view rebirth as the passing of a flame from one candle to another, not as a candle (an individual soul) that burns for all eternity. This cycle continues until the person extinguishes the three fires (passion, hate, and ignorance) and achieves true happiness—a state called Nirvana. Achieving Nirvana allows the Buddhist to escape the cycle of life and death.

Worship

While many Buddhists do not worship gods, some do so to share in the merit of enlightened beings as well as to emulate them and to petition them for protection. Many adherents venerate statues of the Buddha.

To follow the Noble Eightfold Path is to be moral, to show compassion for others, to be mindful of one’s thoughts and actions, and to develop wisdom through understanding the Four Noble Truths.

The moral code of Buddhism consists of the following Five Precepts.

  • Refrain from harming or taking the life of any being
  • Refrain from taking or misusing anything which does not belong to you or which was not clearly offered to you
  • Refrain from harmful expressions of sexuality
  • Refrain from harmful expressions of speech
  • Refrain from the use of intoxicants and substances which cloud the mind

Many Buddhist Storm Knights find power within themselves in the form of ki (qi in Chinese). Many Buddhists are pacifists, so Storm Knight followers often learn martial arts techniques but use the minimum amount of force to defend themselves.

The community of adherents as a whole is known as the Sangha. Generally, Buddhism employs no organized hierarchy—all followers are considered equal, but some branches of the faith use ranks, such as the Tibetan Lamas. Monks and nuns typically gather and meditate in monasteries and temples.

Chinese Folk Religion

China has a diverse variety of religions. Minorities of Christians and Muslims live along the country’s borders, but most Chinese who profess to having a faith practice a broad folk religion as a base belief system. Many people incorporate Taoism, Confucianism, and Buddhism into their folk beliefs, and some people follow parts of all three, as demonstrated by the saying, “Every Chinese wears a Confucian cap, a Taoist robe, and Buddhist sandals.”

Taoism is a philosophy that stresses living in harmony with Tao , which means theWay. Itwas first described by the ancient Chinese philosopher Lao Tzu roughly 2,500 years ago, and it grew to be the traditional faith of China. It now boasts only about six million followers, the vast majority of which reside in China, with some living in Malaysia.

The philosophy of Confucianism, founded by the Chinese philosopher Confucius around 2,500 years ago, encourages adherents to consider consequences before acting, rather than blindly following authority or by leaving one’s fate to chance.

At least 300 million people practice a traditional Chinese folk religion in some form. Most of these worshipers reside in China and Taiwan, but some are also found in Malaysia.

Tenets

Chinese religions are less strict than other faiths regarding doctrine, and belief systems can grow and change organically as time passes. Many of these beliefs are an inherent part of Chinese culture, not just part of a faith. Here are some of the basic tenants:

  • A good life and afterlife are gained through rituals and the reverence of the ancestors of one’s household
  • Nature has two complimentary yet contrary forces: yin and yang, and these forces are very important in Chinese cosmology
  • Yin is the negative and passive force, often associated with femininity, while yang is the positive and active force, and associated with masculinity
  • Some spirits manifest yin (malicious kuei), and yang (benign shen).
  • The gods are actually supernatural humans rather than gods (as people from other faiths would view them), and include heroes like emperors and other important Taoist or Buddhist figures.
  • According to adherents, Taoism is much more than a religion or philosophy. It is a way of life that teaches understanding and an acceptance of oneself (in other words, going with the flow). Additionally, Taoists do not assign good or bad acpects to yin and yang; both are necessary for a balanced life.
  • Confucianists support mercy, social order, acting on your responsibilities, and placing family before the individual. They act according to li (the proper way), rules of social interaction conducted between the person and the state, between family members, and between strangers. Conformity is highly valued.

Worship

Because adherents of Chinese folk religion have no set scriptures to follow, no set theology, and no dictated hierarchy, worship varies acording to the individual. The most important aspect of this faith is one’s family, and ancestor worship is common. Some adherents worship local deities, animal totems, and spirits, as well.

Rituals form the basis of Chinese worship, and communication with spirits forms a central component of these rituals. The homes of particular important historical figures often become centers of worship for those who revere these individuals.

Christianity

Christianity is the world’s largest religion, with nearly 2.5 billion adherents. It is a monotheistic religion based on the teachings of Jesus, a Jewish prophet who was executed by the Roman Empire. Christianity has several denominational families, the largest of which is Catholicism with the Pope as the head of the Church which has most of its followers in Europe (especially Italy and Spain) and Latin America. Other large denominations include Protestants and Anglicans (most of whom live in the United Kingdom, northern Europe, the USA, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, and sub-Saharan Africa), and Orthodox Christians (most of whom live in Eastern Europe and Russia). Over time, many schisms led to the creatiion of other denominations, such as the Oriental Orthodox, the Jehovah’s Witnesses, and the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints (better known as the Mormons).

Tenets

With the large number of denominations, there are plenty of differences in beliefs and practices. However, there are some aspects of Christianity that practically all of the Christian sects believe:

  • A supreme deity, God, created the world and the universe.
  • Jesus Christ was the son of God, as conceived by the Holy Spirit and the Virgin Mary
  • Jesus is the Messiah, or God’s Anointed, whose coming was foretold in prophecies of the Old Testament (the sacred scriptures that discuss the covenant between God and the Jews). Christians follow a new covenant in the form of the New Testament (sacred scriptures not shared by the Jews).
  • Although Christians and Jews share the Hebrew Scriptures (which Christians call the Old Testament), their interpretations of these scriptures differ vastly. The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints and the Christian Scientists base their doctrines on additional revealed books, a practice that leads some to categorize them as different religions, not Christian denominations.
  • Christians believe that there is only one Godhead, but he exists as Three Persons (Father, Son, and Holy Spirit). Several sects, including the Jehovah’s Witnesses and the Mormons, do not accept this tenet.
  • Jesus was sent by God to absolve humanity of the original sin of disobeying God by eating from the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil. Jesus achieved this by being crucified, dying, resurrecting, and eventually ascending directly to heaven.
  • Humans who believe in Jesus, accept his teachings, and ask for forgiveness of their sins, or are baptized, are saved and gain eternal life in Heaven. Those who do not receive eternal damnation in Hell. Some sects, like Jehova’s Witnesses, do not believe in eternal damnation and suffering, and point to the Book of Revelations as evidence.
  • Jesus will return to Earth in a second coming, raise the dead, and invoke a final judgement on the world.
  • Although not a core doctrine, many believe in seven cardinal virtues: chastity, temperance (meaning having a calm mind), charity, diligence, patience, kindness, and humility. These are mirrored by the seven so-called deadly sins: lust, gluttony, greed, sloth, wrath, envy, and pride.

Worship

Ceremonies and processes of worship vary significantly by denomination, and many schisms erupted simply because of disagreements over details of belief and methods of worship. However, significant similarities remain, including: meeting in a church on Sunday, the playing of music (often with a choir), prayer, the collection of tithes, and sermons led by an individual whom the church grants special powers and privileges. These powers and privileges vary by denomination, as does the title for this leader.

Many denominations, including the Catholics, the Anglicans, and the Oriental and Eastern Orthodox churches practice an elaborate and formal ceremony known sometimes as Mass, Eucharist, or Communion, in which followers consume a sacramental bread and wine (the body and blood of Jesus) while praising Jesus for dying for their sins. This ceremony is based on the story of the Last Supper, which tells of the final encounter between Jesus and his disciples before his crucifixion. Catholics in particular believe this bread and wine undergo transubstantiation to become the literal flesh and blood of Christ. Others view the Eucharist as symbolic only. The Catholic, Orthodox, and Anglican churches find particular value in the performance of sacred rituals they believe Jeses ordained for the church as a means to remove sins and purify believers.

There are two main styles of worship in Christianity. One is very formalized and usually led by a priest. Worshipers believe the sacraments are a special manifestation of God’s saving power. Examples of this include Roman Catholic, Anglican, and Orthodox churches, and typically require formal prayer books and ritualized services. The other main style, often but not exclusively Protestant, rarely uses prayer books, is often led by ministers or pastors, not priests, and contends that sacraments are symbolic or memorial acts, not literal manifestations. There is a third kind of worship—ecstatic—in which people undergo emotional or psychological experiences that are often more expressive and vocal than the other forms practiced by organized Christianity. Some ecstatic worship even results in possession by the Holy Spirit, being slain by the Spirit (in other words, fainting), and/or speaking in tongues, which is babbling unintelligible words or speaking a different language. Ecstatic worship is uncommon and crosses denominational lines.

Indigenous Religions

When Europeans explored the world, they came across many different indigenous faiths, too numerous to completely list here. Literally thousands of tribes were found globally. These included the First Nations (the Native Americans, Inuit, and tribes such as the Mexica or Aztecs) of North and Central America, the pueblos idígenas of South America, the Aborigines of Australia, the Māori of New Zealand, and the Polynesian people of the islands in the Pacific Ocean.

Tenets

With the global reach and diverse beliefs of aboriginal peoples, there is no unified belief system, and it would be impossible to list the beliefs of every faith, though common threads run through various faiths. Some non-indigenous people practice faiths collectively known as neoshamanism, which combines elements from a variety of indigenous beliefs. The core practices of this syncretic faith are as follows.

  • Everything is alive and possesses a spirit. This includes people, other animals, plants, and even inanimate objects such as the land and the sea. The land and sea are considered particularly sacred, though all spirits are connected in a web of relationships. Human spirits are not superior to any others, and wealth is meant to benefit the entire community, not merely a few individuals. Some of these spirits act as guardians.
  • Many spirits are considered gods, and often the spirits elevated to godhood are those elements of nature that have the greatest effect on a particular people. These include the volcano gods in Hawaii, the Mexica sun and war god Huitzilopochtli, and Nanook, the master of bears of the Inuit.
  • Many faiths believe in tricksters, either spirits or gods, such as Coyote for the Mohawks, and Māui in Māori religion. Many tricksters are shape shifters, like Nanabush of the Ojibwe. All can transform freely between animal and human form, and some can assume the shape of inanimate objects as well.
  • Many believe that a creator god or Great Spirit created the world and everything on it. Some stories tell of a spirit or cultural hero who dives into the ocean and brings back mud that forms the Earth. Other indigenous faiths believe the Earth sits on the back of a turtle.
  • Time is circular, not linear, and features cycles. These cycles can include the sun rising each day, the moon changing phases each month, and the seasons coming and going each year. These cycles play out in the Mayan Long Count, the calendar represented bywheelsthatmesh together like gears. Aboriginal peoples of Australia tell of a Dreamtime, during which their ancestors created the world. Dreamtime is also called the time-out-of-time and comprises past, present, and future all at once.
  • Circles appear often in aboriginal beliefs. Not only do aborigines consider time circular, many of their dances incorporate hoops, and circles often figure prominently in their religious ceremonies.

Worship

Just as beliefs vary, so too do methods of worship. The following are examples of various peoples’ worldviews and practices.

  • Shamans (originally used for the spiritual leaders of the Tungus people) are a tribe’s healers, prophets, and storytellers. Some of a shaman’s abilities are spiritual, but others stem from an arcane source. Many shamans carry medicine bundles that contain objects and materials infused with power.
  • Youths, usually males, conduct vision quests, often to experience a vision or contact a guardian spirit. The result of such efforts is health and prosperity or the revelation of the supplicant’s purpose in life. These quests often consist of journeying to remote areas to fast, pray, and purify oneself.
  • Many peoples make use of sweat lodges—domes heated with a fire pit and humidified by steam—as a way to connect with the creator spirit and to cleanse the mind, body, and soul.
  • Ceremonial dancing is common and features extravagant costumes, face painting or masks, singing, and the beating of drums.

As an egalitarian worldview, there is no set hierarchy in indigenous faiths. Shamans may have knowledge and power, but they use them to serve the community as a whole. No individual is considered more important than any other.

Islam

Islam is observed by over a billion people worldwide, mostly concentrated in North Africa, the Middle East, India, and Indonesia. It is a monotheistic religion which, along with Judaism and Christianity, traces its origin to the Abraham of the Old Testament.

Tenets

Most Muslims belive in the following primary tenets.

  • There is but one god, Allah (Arabic for the God), who created the universe and everything within it. The purpose of existence is to worship and glorify him. Allah is omniscient and omnipotent—he has full knowledge and control over all events, though humans can choose between right and wrong and are responsible for their actions.
  • Angels are the servants of Allah. They have no free will and are celestial beings of light or fire. An angel’s purpose is to communicate revelations from Allah, to glorify him, to record everyone’s actions during life, and to convey peoples’ souls to judgment after death.
  • The prophets are humans chosen by Allah to be his messengers. No prophet is divine, although some performed miracles. Adam, Noah, Abraham, Moses, and Jesus were prophets. Muhammad, the author of the Qur’an, was God’s last prophet.
  • The Qur’an is the final revelation, as presented to Muhammad by the archangel Gabriel. Other Holy books—such as the Torah and the Gospels—became distorted; only the Qur’an contains the true word of Allah.
  • There will come a Day of Resurrection, when all humans are judged on their deeds and sent to Paradise or Hell. Allah may forgive the sins of those who repent. Sins include (but are not limited to) denying the existence of Allah, identifying physical objects with Allah, murder, practicing magic, stealing, and failing to pray. Some virtues are charity, prayer, courtesy, generosity, humility, and kindness.

Islam is not monolithic; the faith comprises several sects. The largest denomination are Sunnis who believe Muhammad, before his death, did not appoint a successor to lead the faith. Sunnis also believe new leaders should be chosen by consensus. They do not believe in a messiah.

Shia Muslims, who are the majority in Iran and Iraq, believe Muhammad’s descendants inherited a special spiritual and political authority over the Muslim community. These imams are without sin. The 12th and final Imam (with a capital I) disappeared about 1,200 years ago but is believed to still be alive. He will return as the Mahdi, or messiah, and rid the world of evil.

A third significant sect, the Sufi, is more contemplative and mystical. Numerous other sub-sects and splinter groups exist, all more-or-less accepted as Muslim depending on the tolerance of the local majority groups.

Worship

The Pillars of Islam focus on five acts which every Muslim must perform. These include the following.

  • The Shahada, a testimony of faith. “There is no god but God. Muhammad is the messenger of God.” Shiites often add a third statement—“Ali is the protector of Allah.”
  • Ritual prayers, or salah, conducted five times per day: at dawn, before sunrise; midday, just after noon; late afternoon, just after sunset; and between sunset and midnight. These prayers are recited in Arabic while facing the Kaaba in Mecca, Saudi Arabia.
  • Those who can do so must give alms to the poor or needy.
  • The faithful may consume no food or drink from dawn to dusk during the holy month of Ramadhan
  • All who are able to do so must make a pilgrimage, or hajj, to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijjah at least once during their lifetime.

Sunni Islam uses no organized hierarchy or ordained priesthood. No person is closer to Allah than others, but some people are demonstrably more knowledgeable about Islam. Islam has a legal system for judging the correctness of a believer’s actions regarding the teachings of the Qur’an. Those with education in interpreting the legalities of conduct (imams) often serve as the de facto leaders in Sunni Islam, though the various legal schools of thought often differ in their determinations.

Shia clerics view themselves as representatives of the 12th Imam, and lay people view them as the interpreters of the Qur’an. The mujtahid are the lowest rank in the clergy, and above them are mubellegh al risala (carrier of the message), hojat al Islam (authority on Islam), ayatollah, and grand ayatollah.

Hinduism

The world’s third largest religion, Hinduism, is arguably the world’s oldest faith. Hindus live mainly in India and Nepal, though growing populations are found in neighboring countries, as well as in Guyana, the USA, Canada, South Africa, Australia, and New Zealand.

Tenets

Hinduism is a diverse faith with many different sects, several scriptures, and millions of gods. Because of the many different schools of Hinduism, each may share elements in common with some but not with others.

Some sects believe in only one god, Brahma, who is thought to envelop and inhabit all parts of the universe. Brahma is unknowable but is often said to have three facets: Brahma the Creator, Vishnu the Preserver, and Shiva the Destroyer. Some sects believe that all creation is God, or that the world is a part of God, or that God is separate and distinct from the universe. Other sects believe gods do not exist, or accept that a creator god formed the universe but otherwise doesn’t interact with it.

The key unified characteristic of Hinduism is the status of the Vedas, the most important scriptures of Hindiusm, which contain rituals, stories, hymns, and other aspects of the faith. A sect that considers these texts sacred is considered part of Hinduism. The nation of India has strong ties to the history described within the Vedas. This deep connection helps all Hindu sects embrace Indian culture in some fashion—a fact that is arguably more important than the number or nature of a sect’s deities.

Many sects share the following aspects of the Hindu faith.

  • Because Brahma is everything, everything—including mankind—is divine.
  • The ultimate goal is to unite with Brahma and transcend the physical self. This unification is known as moksha. Until this happens, the Hindu follower reincarnates continually.
  • Society is organized by caste, which is assigned according to birth. The brahmin (priests) sit at the top of the hierarchy, followed by the kshatriyas (administrators, nobles, rajahs, and warriors), the vaisyas (farmers, artisans, craftspeople, and merchants), and the shudras (laborers). The lowest level, the so-called untouchables, exist outside of the caste system.
  • Karma is the balance of all the right and wrong that a person chooses. This include thoughts, speech, actions chosen directly, and actions chosen by others indirectly. Fate does not exist—karma is determined strictly by past actions.
  • Karma’s effects propagate across lifetimes, and actions and thoughts from past lives can influence the here and now. It also influences a soul’s new form after reincarnation, determining whether you return as a lowly worm, a higher animal, or a human, the highest form.
  • Major sins are as varied as the sects. Some are more specific than others (for example, creating computer viruses, or committing adultery…but only with a guru’s wife), while some common sins are more easily defined (stealing, killing, lying, or destroying knowledge, for example).
  • Virtues vary as well, and different schools of thought place different importance on different behaviors. Examples include pacifism, purity, truthfulness, temperance, courage, and forgiveness.

Worship

Unlike many major religions, worship in Hinduism is much more personal. Many adherents maintain shrines in their own homes. Shrines can be as simple as small altars or even just pictures or statues of the follower’s favorite gods or goddesses. Hindu temples exist as well, allowing for a more communal worship. Hindu priests (or pundits) train, often from childhood, to lead services (puja) from memory in Sanskrit. Pundits often are male, but there is growing acceptance of female pundits in areas where no man is available or willing to serve in that role.

Hindus make offerings while repeating a deity’s name and reciting mantras. These offerings include things such as water, food, flowers, and incense. Some worshipers wear a sacred fabric that hangs over the left shoulder and extends to the right hip.

Pilgrimage is important to Hindus and involves journeying to a location where a god or goddess appeared in the world. Such places include sacred sites, mountains, temples, and rivers. Two particularly important locations are the Ganges river and the city of Varanasi, which sits on the Ganges. The journey is just as important as the destination, and adherents view any struggles along the way as acts of devotion. Hindus believe visiting a sacred place is an act of purification that brings them closer to Brahma.

Judaism

Judaism is an ancient, monotheistic, Abrahamic religion practiced by about 14 million people worldwide, most of whom live in Israel and the United States.

Tenets

There are several different sects of Judaism, including Orthodox and Reform, so there is no unified view of Judaism and nearly all aspects of Judaims are debated. However, some common Jewish beliefs include the following.

  • There is one God, and he is the creator of the universe, though this may be meant in a figurative sense as most Jews do not believe the creation account presented in Genesis. God is eternal, with no beginning and no end. Scholars also commonly debate whether God is all-knowing, all-powerful, and perfectly good, or whether God encompasses all things good and evil.
  • A person prays to God only, not to his angels or prophets, or other figures representing Him.
  • The Tanakh is the Hebrew Bible. The Tanakh includes three parts: the Torah (Teachings), which include the Five Books of Moses (Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, and Deuteronomy); the Nevi’im (Prophets) which includes historical accounts and books written by the prophets; and the Ketuvim (Writings) which include Psalms and Proverbs plus other philosophical writings.
  • The Torah (Teachings) is believed to have two parts: Written, and Oral. Orthodox Jews believe God revealed the Torah to Moses. The ancient Rabbis recorded much of the attendant oral tradition in the Talmud, a collection of legal essays that reflect rabbinical thinking during the first several centuries CE. The Torah is the Revealed Word of God, but understanding of the Torah comes only through study of Talmudic interpretations of the ancient rabbis, not solely from the text. Reform Jews typically view the Torah as sacred but not necessarily as a direct revelation from God; they place more emphasis on the ethical precepts of the text rather than on any religious aspects of the Torah. Between these two poles there is a wide variety of interpretations and understandings of the place of ritual and cultural practices—such as kosher (sacred eating) food in Jewish life).
  • Judaism espouses practice over belief. Belief and desire to do good are nice but not required to act ethically (or even religiously, in Orthodox circles).
  • As an ancient religion, ethnicity and religion intertwine in ways not seen in other faiths. To be a Muslim is to accept and believe the tenents of Islam. But many Jews, especially in Israel, are Jewish by culture and ethnicity, not by belief. This is more akin to Hinduism’s integration with Indian culture or the native shamanic traditions rather than other world religions.
  • Humans have free will and may choose to do good or evil. Original sin does not exist; all people are responsible for their actions. God rewards those who observe his commandments and punishes those who disobey intentionally (depending on their viewpoint, some people view this as either a literal or a metaphoric reward).
  • Judaism has no singlular intepretation of (or belief in) the afterlife, but some Jews believe God sends the righteous to Gan Eden, a place of spiritual perfection. Unworthy souls travel to Gehinnom, a place of punishment and purification. Most souls spend only a short time in Gehinnom, as Judaism has no concept of eternal damnation. For most Jews, living a good life is its own reward, and few concern about the afterlife are rare, unlike with other religions, which focus on the afterlife.
  • Different peoples of the world were chosen by God to fulfil some distinct purpose. The Jewish people were chosen to be the pioneers of religion and morality. This is not to say that Jews are better than anyone else, but it does affirm Judaism’s historic role in bringing monotheism to the world.
  • The messiah, an anointed leader descended from King David, is still yet to come but Jews do not consider him divine.

Worship

Prayers are central to Jewish worship, and these prayers are found in the siddur, the traditional prayer book. Jews are expected to recite prayers three times daily, with additional prayers on the Sabbath (which begins Friday afternoon and continues until Saturday evening) and on Jewish holidays.

Jewish holidays last from sunset the day before the given date of the holiday until the end of dusk on the date of the holiday. Judaism uses a soli-lunar calendar which is quite ancient and complicated, although computerization makes the calculations easier (many Jews get details from their favorite websites). Major Jewish holidays include Passover (which commemorates the Exodus from Egypt), The Days of Awe (which include Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year], and Yom Kippur [the day of atonement].American Jews count Chanukah (which commemorates the rededication of the Temple in Jerusalem) among the most significant holidays.

Judaism employs no organized hierarchy. Rabbis are qualified by their branch of the faith to teach Jewish law and to adjudicate questions of religious observance. In most denominations they are the paid religious leaders of a synagogue (a religious community), but in small communities there may just be a volunteer prayer leader. Other religious professionals include the Cantor or Hazzan (a worship leader trained in music and singing), Kohenot (religious ritualists who specialize in feminist rituals and worship), and Jewish religious educators (Jews place great value on education—both secular and sacred).

There is no intermediary between a worshiper and God. The exception to this is with the Rebbes—dynastic teachers and leaders of the charismatic Jewish sects known as Hasidim. Many consider their Rebbe a combination of messiah and guru, and some ask guidance from deceased Rebbes similar to the ways Catholics ask saints for intervention. However even Hasidim have no need for a mediator between worshipper and God.

Neopaganism

Neopaganism is a collection of recent religious movements rooted in the historical faiths of pre-Christian and pre-Muslim Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East. The largest neopagan faith is Wicca, or witchfcraft—a duotheistic faith that believes ritual can influence the physical world through magic. Other beliefs include Neo-Druidism, based on the ancient religion of the Celts; Heathenism, a Germanic pagan faith based on the gods of Norse mythology; and New Age paganism which focuses on nature and environmental activism. Most Neopagans of various types live in Canada, the USA, and in Europe (particularly the United Kingdom and Scandinavia).

Tenets

Although the different varieties of neopagan faiths differ on many details, there are some aspects of the faiths that they tend to have in common, although there are few if any absolutes.

  • The belief in multiple gods or goddesses which might be actual beings, or represent human culture, or psychological archetypes manifesting, or incarnations of nature.
  • The gods and goddesses are wise and powerful, but are not perfect and have human faults.
  • Women, especially women’s sexual/generative power, are venerated much more than in other faiths.
  • All things in the universe are interconnected. Some pagans believe that all things have a life force. Others believe that spirits live in various parts of nature, including animals, rocks, and plants. Many revere the Earth itself as a goddess, known as Gaia.

Various neopagan faiths each tend to worship particular deities. Examples include the following.

  • Wicca: The Moon Goddess and the Horned God. Some Wiccan sects expand the pantheon to include other deities, and use the prefix Greater when referring to the primary deities.
  • Heathenism: The ancient Norse gods—including Thor (God of Thunder), Odin (God of Wisdom), Loki (the Trickster God), Freya (Goddess of Love), Heimdall (Guardian of Asgard), and many others.
  • Neo-Druids worship Nature as a whole, and the spirits that inhabit it. They have no particular pantheon of gods or goddesses, though they often worship the Goddess directly. Additionally, Neo-Druids revere ancestors of the land and also those with whom they share a spiritual connection, rather than their direct DNA ancestors.
  • New Age pagans believe in the divine, but the exact nature of this divinity varies by the individual. Human minds cannot fully understand this divinity but people generally view it as the whole of the universe. It is intelligent, it takes the form of an energy or life force, and it consists of love.

Worship

Just asvariousNeopagan religions exhibit different beliefs, Neopagan worship varies significantly as well. Neopagan rituals often involve drumming, chanting, and singing, and many rituals take on whimsical aspects not seen in many other faiths.

Their rituals can be conducted in public or in private, and offerings to deities mainly involve food and drink. Public rituals are usually associated with festivals based on the natural calendar and emphasizing solstices, equinoxes, and harvests.

Some Neopagans, including Wiccans and Neodruids, use magical rituals that involve spells. These rituals often involve a sacred circle, and although witchcraft suffered a negative connotation for centuries, Wiccans and Neodruids practice what they term white magic, casting spells used in the application of healing, protection or fertility.

Sikhism

Sikhism is a relatively recent addition to the world religion stage, claiming more than 20 million followers worldwide. Most adherents of this faith reside in the Punjab region of India, but significant populations migrated overseas.

The largest Sikh populations live in the United States and Canada (particularly in British Columbia). Sikhism arose 500 years ago from the teachings of Gurk Nanak along with those of nine succeeding gurus, the tenth of which declared the scripture Guru Granth Sahib would be his successor.

Tenets

The core beliefs of Sikhism, as outlined in the Guru Granth Sahib (sacred scripture) include the following.

  • There is one God. God is without form or gender. All people have direct access to God.
  • All humans are equal; discrimination based on gender, class, race, or sect is prohibited.
  • The three principles of Sikhism are: to work hard and honestly, to share with the needy, and to remember God throughout the day.
  • All Sikhs must be baptized, and the faithful must live their lives according to scripture.
  • Every Sikh must wear five articles of the faith known as the five K’s: uncut hair (the Keshas), a wooden comb (the Kanga), a steel bracelet (the Karha), a sword or dagger called a kirpan, and short trousers (the Kachhehra). Although many unfamiliar with the Sikh faith think the kirpan is a weapon, it is kept sheathed and used only during rituals.
  • Sikhs must follow the four commandments: no use of drugs or alchohol, no cutting of the hair, no consumption of meat destined for sacrifice, and no adultery.
  • Community service and worship is a virtue.

Worship

Unlike many faiths, Sikhism does not exhibit many forms of worship—such as pilgrimages, fasting, and the worship of images or statues—as often occurs in other faiths.

Sikhs pray many times daily—conducting three prayers in the morning, one in the evening at sunset, and one before sleeping. These are known as the Panj Bania.

Sikhs do not employ ordained priests, and any of the faithful can recite scripture and lead others in prayer.

Several festivals are held during the year, most of which are celebrated over a two-day period of reading the whole Guru Granth Sahib. The most important of these are gurpurbs, which mark the birthday or martyrdom of a Guru.

Diwali, one of the most important festivals in India, is also known as the Festival of Light. It takes place during the Western calendar’s month of October or November. Sikhs celebrate the return of Lord Rama from exile, but Hindus and Jains associate other stories with the holiday.

Shinto

Shinto (Way of the Gods) is the traditional faith of Japan. It is significantly intertwined with Japanese culture to the point that even though more than 100 million Japanese observe Shinto rites, only a small proportion of them consider Shinto to be their only religion.

Tenets

The core beliefs of Shinto are as follows.

  • The belief in kami. Kami can be spirits or essences but ultimately are the manifestations of the energy of the universe. Kami include living beings aswell as rocks, rivers, and places. Even the sun, moon, and Earth are kami. Kami care about human suffering and respond to human prayers.
  • Some particularly pious or venerated dead people can become kami themselves, and in fact, many kami are believed to be progenitors of Japanese dynasties.
  • Kami dwell everywhere and in all objects. Certain places or things (known as yorishiro or shintai) enable people to interact with kami.
  • Some kami are personified and worshipped as divinities, but they are integral to the Earth and not separate from it the way they can be in transcendent religions. The most famous kami is Amaterasu, the goddess of the sun, the universe, and the High Celestrial Plain, and the ancestors of the Emperors of Japan. She is the daughter of Izanami and Izanagi, the creators of the Earth.
  • Different kami have polarized tendencies, and negative kami exist to oppose each positive kami (for example, fire versus water, or the sun versus the moon)
  • The pantheon and areas of influence of kami can change and evolve. As Japanese culture and knowledge changed, some kami domains expanded to include new discoveries. One such example is Hosogami, the kami of smallpox. As scientific understanding improved, his domain expanded to cover all contagious diseases.

Worship

Shinto shrines dot Japan but only a small minority belong to an organized Shinto community. Shrines can even be found inside worshipers’ homes. Each shrine is devoted to a single kami, but shrines are so ubiquitous across Japan that many different kami are always close at hand when followers feel the need to pray.

Shinto festivals (matsuri) honor specific kami. These festivals require purification and an offering made at a shrine. Many events occur during a typical celebration, including plays, parades, sumo wrestling matches, and feasts.

Japanese life blends Shinto with Buddhism, and circumstances dictate which ritual to perform. For example, adherants may have a Shinto wedding but a Buddhist funeral (Shinto rituals focus on life and cleansing worhsipers from the polluting effects of death).

Other Religions

The people of Core Earth practice countless other faiths and beliefs, and limitations of space prevent us from explaining them all. Here are just a few of these faiths and belief systems.

Atheism and Secular Humanism: Atheism is the belief that no deities exist. Secular humanism takes it a step further, stating humans are capable of acting moral without guidance or interference from gods, spirits, or supernatural entities of any kind. With the invasion from other realities, especially those featuring powerful miracles (like the Living Land, the Nile Empire, and the Cyberpapacy), secular humanists softened their stance significantly. Many now accept that gods and spirits exist in some places but they don’t necessarily exist in all places. Also, people can still be morally and ethically ‘good’ without worshiping these deities. Still, some secular humanists remain dogmatic and refuse to believe in miracles, even when the evidence is plentiful, instead attributing such effects to trickery or even—begrudgingly—magic. Atheists and secular humanists do not invoke miracles.

Bahá’í: A growing, globally-distributed religion of over 5 million believers that originated in Iran in the mid 19th century. Bahá’ís believe that (with the invasion) all of the cosmverse’s religions reveal aspects of a single, universal God and none are more right or wrong than any other because God is ultimately incomprehensible. Adherents also believe that all humans (and elves, dwarves, edeinos, and other sapient beings) are equal.

Jainism: Jainism is an ancient Indian faith of about 4 million followers with some similarities with Buddhism and Hinduism. Jains are concerned with the welfare of all beings in the cosmverse, and even for the health of the cosmverse itself. They believe that all living things, even non-sentient animals and plants, house a soul, and that each of these souls should be treated with equal compassion.

Like other Indian faiths, Jains believe in reincarnation and attempt to liberate themselves from the unending cycle of life and death by eliminating all karma from their soul. They do not believe in any gods or spiritual beings that can aid humanity (or now, other sentient races). Humanity can only rely on itself.Although they believe in non-violence, and so do not directly take to the field to fight the forces of the High Lords, many Jains have joined the Delphi Council because they believe the cosmverse itself is threatened. They generally take on support roles within the organization.

Unitarian Universalist: The members of this faith believe that every person is equal and worthy of dignity, and also all should be accepted and encouraged to grow spiritually. Unitarian Universalists come from a variety of faiths, and even include agnostics and atheists, and they teach that all faiths and belief systems offer valuable lessons. Since the invasion, UUs accepted those who worship Lanala, many who follow the Aylish Gods of Light, and even a couple of Amaatists. While those who worship the Cyberpapal or Sacellum versions of Christianity are welcome to join the church, none have due to their strict denial of the validity of other religions. The UU faith has a global reach, though most followers live in the United States.

Vodou: Also known as Voodoo, this faith is primarily practiced in Haiti or by those originally from that nation. Vodouisants believe the body and soul are tied together and that the soul can also be tied to tangible objects. They believe in a supreme diety named Bondye, but he is unreachable, so practitioners instead pray to lesser spirts known as loa. Roman Catholicism is connected to Vodou, and each loa is often also associated with a Catholic saint. Although many believe voodoo dolls (and the practice of sticking them with needles) and the creation of zombies are associated with vodou, these acts are actually arcane in nature.
